mdText: The light of the eyes rejoiceth the heart: _and_ a good report maketh the bones fat.

verseText: The ear that heareth the reproof of life abideth among the wise.
mdText: The ear that heareth the reproof of life abideth among the wise.

verseText: He that refuseth instruction despiseth his own soul: but he that heareth reproof getteth understanding.
mdText: He that refuseth instruction despiseth his own soul: but he that heareth reproof getteth understanding.

verseText: The fear of the LORD is the instruction of wisdom; and before honour is humility.
mdText: The fear of the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) _is_ the instruction of wisdom; and before honour _is_ humility.

verseText: The preparations of the heart in man, and the answer of the tongue, is from the LORD.
mdText: The preparations of the heart in man, and the answer of the tongue, _is_ from the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: All the ways of a man are clean in his own eyes; but the LORD weigheth the spirits.
mdText: All the ways of a man _are_ clean in his own eyes; but the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) weigheth the spirits.

verseText: Commit thy works unto the LORD, and thy thoughts shall be established.
mdText: Commit thy works unto the [LORD,]([/person/god_1324) and thy thoughts shall be established.

verseText: The LORD hath made all things for himself: yea, even the wicked for the day of evil.
mdText: The [LORD]([/person/god_1324) hath made all _things_ for himself: yea, even the wicked for the day of evil.

verseText: Every one that is proud in heart is an abomination to the LORD: though hand join in hand, he shall not be unpunished.
mdText: Every one _that_ _is_ proud in heart _is_ an abomination to the [LORD:]([/person/god_1324) _though_ hand _join_ in hand, he shall not be unpunished.

verseText: By mercy and truth iniquity is purged: and by the fear of the LORD men depart from evil.
mdText: By mercy and truth iniquity is purged: and by the fear of the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) _men_ depart from evil.

verseText: When a man’s ways please the LORD, he maketh even his enemies to be at peace with him.
mdText: When a man’s ways please the [LORD,]([/person/god_1324) he maketh even his enemies to be at peace with him.

verseText: Better is a little with righteousness than great revenues without right.
mdText: Better _is_ a little with righteousness than great revenues without right.

verseText: A man’s heart deviseth his way: but the LORD directeth his steps.
mdText: A man’s heart deviseth his way: but the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) directeth his steps.

verseText: A divine sentence is in the lips of the king: his mouth transgresseth not in judgment.
mdText: A divine sentence _is_ in the lips of the king: his mouth transgresseth not in judgment.

verseText: A just weight and balance are the LORD’S: all the weights of the bag are his work.
mdText: A just weight and balance _are_ the [LORD’S:]([/person/god_1324) all the weights of the bag _are_ his work.

verseText: It is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness: for the throne is established by righteousness.
mdText: _It_ _is_ an abomination to kings to commit wickedness: for the throne is established by righteousness.

verseText: Righteous lips are the delight of kings; and they love him that speaketh right.
mdText: Righteous lips _are_ the delight of kings; and they love him that speaketh right.

verseText: The wrath of a king is as messengers of death: but a wise man will pacify it.
mdText: The wrath of a king _is_ _as_ messengers of death: but a wise man will pacify it.

verseText: In the light of the king’s countenance is life; and his favour is as a cloud of the latter rain.
mdText: In the light of the king’s countenance _is_ life; and his favour _is_ as a cloud of the latter rain.

verseText: How much better is it to get wisdom than gold! and to get understanding rather to be chosen than silver!
mdText: How much better _is_ _it_ to get wisdom than gold! and to get understanding rather to be chosen than silver!

verseText: The highway of the upright is to depart from evil: he that keepeth his way preserveth his soul.
mdText: The highway of the upright _is_ to depart from evil: he that keepeth his way preserveth his soul.

verseText: Pride goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall.
mdText: Pride _goeth_ before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall.

verseText: Better it is to be of an humble spirit with the lowly, than to divide the spoil with the proud.
mdText: Better _it_ _is_ _to_ _be_ of an humble spirit with the lowly, than to divide the spoil with the proud.

verseText: He that handleth a matter wisely shall find good: and whoso trusteth in the LORD, happy is he.
mdText: He that handleth a matter wisely shall find good: and whoso trusteth in the [LORD,]([/person/god_1324) happy _is_ he.

verseText: The wise in heart shall be called prudent: and the sweetness of the lips increaseth learning.
mdText: The wise in heart shall be called prudent: and the sweetness of the lips increaseth learning.

verseText: Understanding is a wellspring of life unto him that hath it: but the instruction of fools is folly.
mdText: Understanding _is_ a wellspring of life unto him that hath it: but the instruction of fools _is_ folly.

verseText: The heart of the wise teacheth his mouth, and addeth learning to his lips.
mdText: The heart of the wise teacheth his mouth, and addeth learning to his lips.

verseText: Pleasant words are as an honeycomb, sweet to the soul, and health to the bones.
mdText: Pleasant words _are_ _as_ an honeycomb, sweet to the soul, and health to the bones.

verseText: There is a way that seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death.
mdText: There is a way that seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof _are_ the ways of death.

verseText: He that laboureth laboureth for himself; for his mouth craveth it of him.
mdText: He that laboureth laboureth for himself; for his mouth craveth it of him.

verseText: An ungodly man diggeth up evil: and in his lips there is as a burning fire.
mdText: An ungodly man diggeth up evil: and in his lips _there_ _is_ as a burning fire.

verseText: A froward man soweth strife: and a whisperer separateth chief friends.
mdText: A froward man soweth strife: and a whisperer separateth chief friends.

verseText: A violent man enticeth his neighbour, and leadeth him into the way that is not good.
mdText: A violent man enticeth his neighbour, and leadeth him into the way _that_ _is_ not good.

verseText: He shutteth his eyes to devise froward things: moving his lips he bringeth evil to pass.
mdText: He shutteth his eyes to devise froward things: moving his lips he bringeth evil to pass.

verseText: The hoary head is a crown of glory, if it be found in the way of righteousness.
mdText: The hoary head _is_ a crown of glory, _if_ it be found in the way of righteousness.

verseText: He that is slow to anger is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his spirit than he that taketh a city.
mdText: _He_ _that_ _is_ slow to anger _is_ better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his spirit than he that taketh a city.

verseText: The lot is cast into the lap; but the whole disposing thereof is of the LORD.
mdText: The lot is cast into the lap; but the whole disposing thereof _is_ of the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: Better is a dry morsel, and quietness therewith, than an house full of sacrifices with strife.
mdText: Better _is_ a dry morsel, and quietness therewith, than an house full of sacrifices _with_ strife.

verseText: A wise servant shall have rule over a son that causeth shame, and shall have part of the inheritance among the brethren.
mdText: A wise servant shall have rule over a son that causeth shame, and shall have part of the inheritance among the brethren.

verseText: The fining pot is for silver, and the furnace for gold: but the LORD trieth the hearts.
mdText: The fining pot _is_ for silver, and the furnace for gold: but the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) trieth the hearts.

verseText: A wicked doer giveth heed to false lips; and a liar giveth ear to a naughty tongue.
mdText: A wicked doer giveth heed to false lips; _and_ a liar giveth ear to a naughty tongue.

verseText: Whoso mocketh the poor reproacheth his Maker: and he that is glad at calamities shall not be unpunished.
mdText: Whoso mocketh the poor reproacheth his Maker: _and_ he that is glad at calamities shall not be unpunished.

verseText: Children’s children are the crown of old men; and the glory of children are their fathers.
mdText: Children’s children _are_ the crown of old men; and the glory of children _are_ their fathers.

verseText: Excellent speech becometh not a fool: much less do lying lips a prince.
mdText: Excellent speech becometh not a fool: much less do lying lips a prince.

verseText: A gift is as a precious stone in the eyes of him that hath it: whithersoever it turneth, it prospereth.
mdText: A gift _is_ _as_ a precious stone in the eyes of him that hath it: whithersoever it turneth, it prospereth.

verseText: He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeateth a matter separateth very friends.
mdText: He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeateth a matter separateth _very_ friends.

verseText: A reproof entereth more into a wise man than an hundred stripes into a fool.
mdText: A reproof entereth more into a wise man than an hundred stripes into a fool.

verseText: An evil man seeketh only rebellion: therefore a cruel messenger shall be sent against him.
mdText: An evil _man_ seeketh only rebellion: therefore a cruel messenger shall be sent against him.

verseText: Let a bear robbed of her whelps meet a man, rather than a fool in his folly.
mdText: Let a bear robbed of her whelps meet a man, rather than a fool in his folly.

verseText: Whoso rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.
mdText: Whoso rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.

verseText: The beginning of strife is as when one letteth out water: therefore leave off contention, before it be meddled with.
mdText: The beginning of strife _is_ _as_ when one letteth out water: therefore leave off contention, before it be meddled with.

verseText: He that justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the just, even they both are abomination to the LORD.
mdText: He that justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the just, even they both _are_ abomination to the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: Wherefore is there a price in the hand of a fool to get wisdom, seeing he hath no heart to it?
mdText: Wherefore _is_ _there_ a price in the hand of a fool to get wisdom, seeing _he_ _hath_ no heart _to_ _it?_

verseText: A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
mdText: A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.

verseText: A man void of understanding striketh hands, and becometh surety in the presence of his friend.
mdText: A man void of understanding striketh hands, _and_ becometh surety in the presence of his friend.

verseText: He loveth transgression that loveth strife: and he that exalteth his gate seeketh destruction.
mdText: He loveth transgression that loveth strife: _and_ he that exalteth his gate seeketh destruction.

verseText: He that hath a froward heart findeth no good: and he that hath a perverse tongue falleth into mischief.
mdText: He that hath a froward heart findeth no good: and he that hath a perverse tongue falleth into mischief.

verseText: He that begetteth a fool doeth it to his sorrow: and the father of a fool hath no joy.
mdText: He that begetteth a fool _doeth_ _it_ to his sorrow: and the father of a fool hath no joy.

verseText: A merry heart doeth good like a medicine: but a broken spirit drieth the bones.
mdText: A merry heart doeth good _like_ a medicine: but a broken spirit drieth the bones.

verseText: A wicked man taketh a gift out of the bosom to pervert the ways of judgment.
mdText: A wicked _man_ taketh a gift out of the bosom to pervert the ways of judgment.

verseText: Wisdom is before him that hath understanding; but the eyes of a fool are in the ends of the earth.
mdText: Wisdom _is_ before him that hath understanding; but the eyes of a fool _are_ in the ends of the earth.

verseText: A foolish son is a grief to his father, and bitterness to her that bare him.
mdText: A foolish son _is_ a grief to his father, and bitterness to her that bare him.

verseText: Also to punish the just is not good, nor to strike princes for equity.
mdText: Also to punish the just _is_ not good, _nor_ to strike princes for equity.

verseText: He that hath knowledge spareth his words: and a man of understanding is of an excellent spirit.
mdText: He that hath knowledge spareth his words: _and_ a man of understanding is of an excellent spirit.

verseText: Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise: and he that shutteth his lips is esteemed a man of understanding.
mdText: Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise: _and_ he that shutteth his lips _is_ _esteemed_ a man of understanding.

verseText: Through desire a man, having separated himself, seeketh and intermeddleth with all wisdom.
mdText: Through desire a man, having separated himself, seeketh _and_ intermeddleth with all wisdom.

verseText: A fool hath no delight in understanding, but that his heart may discover itself.
mdText: A fool hath no delight in understanding, but that his heart may discover itself.

verseText: When the wicked cometh, then cometh also contempt, and with ignominy reproach.
mdText: When the wicked cometh, _then_ cometh also contempt, and with ignominy reproach.

verseText: The words of a man’s mouth are as deep waters, and the wellspring of wisdom as a flowing brook.
mdText: The words of a man’s mouth _are_ _as_ deep waters, _and_ the wellspring of wisdom _as_ a flowing brook.

verseText: It is not good to accept the person of the wicked, to overthrow the righteous in judgment.
mdText: _It_ _is_ not good to accept the person of the wicked, to overthrow the righteous in judgment.

verseText: A fool’s lips enter into contention, and his mouth calleth for strokes.
mdText: A fool’s lips enter into contention, and his mouth calleth for strokes.

verseText: A fool’s mouth is his destruction, and his lips are the snare of his soul.
mdText: A fool’s mouth _is_ his destruction, and his lips _are_ the snare of his soul.

verseText: The words of a talebearer are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
mdText: The words of a talebearer _are_ as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.

verseText: He also that is slothful in his work is brother to him that is a great waster.
mdText: He also that is slothful in his work is brother to him that is a great waster.

verseText: The name of the LORD is a strong tower: the righteous runneth into it, and is safe.
mdText: The name of the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) _is_ a strong tower: the righteous runneth into it, and is safe.

verseText: The rich man’s wealth is his strong city, and as an high wall in his own conceit.
mdText: The rich man’s wealth _is_ his strong city, and as an high wall in his own conceit.

verseText: Before destruction the heart of man is haughty, and before honour is humility.
mdText: Before destruction the heart of man is haughty, and before honour _is_ humility.

verseText: He that answereth a matter before he heareth it, it is folly and shame unto him.
mdText: He that answereth a matter before he heareth _it,_ it _is_ folly and shame unto him.

verseText: The spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity; but a wounded spirit who can bear?
mdText: The spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity; but a wounded spirit who can bear?

verseText: The heart of the prudent getteth knowledge; and the ear of the wise seeketh knowledge.
mdText: The heart of the prudent getteth knowledge; and the ear of the wise seeketh knowledge.

verseText: A man’s gift maketh room for him, and bringeth him before great men.
mdText: A man’s gift maketh room for him, and bringeth him before great men.

verseText: He that is first in his own cause seemeth just; but his neighbour cometh and searcheth him.
mdText: _He_ _that_ _is_ first in his own cause _seemeth_ just; but his neighbour cometh and searcheth him.

verseText: The lot causeth contentions to cease, and parteth between the mighty.
mdText: The lot causeth contentions to cease, and parteth between the mighty.

verseText: A brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city: and their contentions are like the bars of a castle.
mdText: A brother offended _is_ _harder_ _to_ _be_ _won_ than a strong city: and _their_ contentions _are_ like the bars of a castle.

verseText: A man’s belly shall be satisfied with the fruit of his mouth; and with the increase of his lips shall he be filled.
mdText: A man’s belly shall be satisfied with the fruit of his mouth; _and_ with the increase of his lips shall he be filled.

verseText: Death and life are in the power of the tongue: and they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.
mdText: Death and life _are_ in the power of the tongue: and they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.

verseText: Whoso findeth a wife findeth a good thing, and obtaineth favour of the LORD.
mdText: _Whoso_ findeth a wife findeth a good _thing,_ and obtaineth favour of the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: The poor useth intreaties; but the rich answereth roughly.
mdText: The poor useth intreaties; but the rich answereth roughly.

verseText: A man that hath friends must shew himself friendly: and there is a friend that sticketh closer than a brother.
mdText: A man _that_ _hath_ friends must shew himself friendly: and there is a friend _that_ sticketh closer than a brother.

verseText: Better is the poor that walketh in his integrity, than he that is perverse in his lips, and is a fool.
mdText: Better _is_ the poor that walketh in his integrity, than _he_ _that_ _is_ perverse in his lips, and is a fool.

verseText: Also, that the soul be without knowledge, it is not good; and he that hasteth with his feet sinneth.
mdText: Also, _that_ the soul _be_ without knowledge, _it_ _is_ not good; and he that hasteth with _his_ feet sinneth.

verseText: The foolishness of man perverteth his way: and his heart fretteth against the LORD.
mdText: The foolishness of man perverteth his way: and his heart fretteth against the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: Wealth maketh many friends; but the poor is separated from his neighbour.
mdText: Wealth maketh many friends; but the poor is separated from his neighbour.

verseText: A false witness shall not be unpunished, and he that speaketh lies shall not escape.
mdText: A false witness shall not be unpunished, and _he_ _that_ speaketh lies shall not escape.

verseText: Many will intreat the favour of the prince: and every man is a friend to him that giveth gifts.
mdText: Many will intreat the favour of the prince: and every man _is_ a friend to him that giveth gifts.

verseText: All the brethren of the poor do hate him: how much more do his friends go far from him? he pursueth them with words, yet they are wanting to him.
mdText: All the brethren of the poor do hate him: how much more do his friends go far from him? he pursueth _them_ _with_ words, _yet_ they _are_ wanting _to_ _him._

verseText: He that getteth wisdom loveth his own soul: he that keepeth understanding shall find good.
mdText: He that getteth wisdom loveth his own soul: he that keepeth understanding shall find good.

verseText: A false witness shall not be unpunished, and he that speaketh lies shall perish.
mdText: A false witness shall not be unpunished, and _he_ _that_ speaketh lies shall perish.

verseText: Delight is not seemly for a fool; much less for a servant to have rule over princes.
mdText: Delight is not seemly for a fool; much less for a servant to have rule over princes.

verseText: The discretion of a man deferreth his anger; and it is his glory to pass over a transgression.
mdText: The discretion of a man deferreth his anger; and _it_ _is_ his glory to pass over a transgression.

verseText: The king’s wrath is as the roaring of a lion; but his favour is as dew upon the grass.
mdText: The king’s wrath _is_ as the roaring of a lion; but his favour _is_ as dew upon the grass.

verseText: A foolish son is the calamity of his father: and the contentions of a wife are a continual dropping.
mdText: A foolish son _is_ the calamity of his father: and the contentions of a wife _are_ a continual dropping.

verseText: House and riches are the inheritance of fathers: and a prudent wife is from the LORD.
mdText: House and riches _are_ the inheritance of fathers: and a prudent wife _is_ from the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: Slothfulness casteth into a deep sleep; and an idle soul shall suffer hunger.
mdText: Slothfulness casteth into a deep sleep; and an idle soul shall suffer hunger.

verseText: He that keepeth the commandment keepeth his own soul; but he that despiseth his ways shall die.
mdText: He that keepeth the commandment keepeth his own soul; _but_ he that despiseth his ways shall die.

verseText: He that hath pity upon the poor lendeth unto the LORD; and that which he hath given will he pay him again.
mdText: He that hath pity upon the poor lendeth unto the [LORD;]([/person/god_1324) and that which he hath given will he pay him again.

verseText: Chasten thy son while there is hope, and let not thy soul spare for his crying.
mdText: Chasten thy son while there is hope, and let not thy soul spare for his crying.

verseText: A man of great wrath shall suffer punishment: for if thou deliver him, yet thou must do it again.
mdText: A man of great wrath shall suffer punishment: for if thou deliver _him,_ yet thou must do it again.

verseText: Hear counsel, and receive instruction, that thou mayest be wise in thy latter end.
mdText: Hear counsel, and receive instruction, that thou mayest be wise in thy latter end.

verseText: There are many devices in a man’s heart; nevertheless the counsel of the LORD, that shall stand.
mdText: _There_ _are_ many devices in a man’s heart; nevertheless the counsel of the [LORD,]([/person/god_1324) that shall stand.

verseText: The desire of a man is his kindness: and a poor man is better than a liar.
mdText: The desire of a man _is_ his kindness: and a poor man _is_ better than a liar.

verseText: The fear of the LORD tendeth to life: and he that hath it shall abide satisfied; he shall not be visited with evil.
mdText: The fear of the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) _tendeth_ to life: and _he_ _that_ _hath_ _it_ shall abide satisfied; he shall not be visited with evil.

verseText: A slothful man hideth his hand in his bosom, and will not so much as bring it to his mouth again.
mdText: A slothful _man_ hideth his hand in _his_ bosom, and will not so much as bring it to his mouth again.

verseText: Smite a scorner, and the simple will beware: and reprove one that hath understanding, and he will understand knowledge.
mdText: Smite a scorner, and the simple will beware: and reprove one that hath understanding, _and_ he will understand knowledge.

verseText: He that wasteth his father, and chaseth away his mother, is a son that causeth shame, and bringeth reproach.
mdText: He that wasteth _his_ father, _and_ chaseth away _his_ mother, _is_ a son that causeth shame, and bringeth reproach.

verseText: Cease, my son, to hear the instruction that causeth to err from the words of knowledge.
mdText: Cease, my son, to hear the instruction _that_ _causeth_ to err from the words of knowledge.

verseText: An ungodly witness scorneth judgment: and the mouth of the wicked devoureth iniquity.
mdText: An ungodly witness scorneth judgment: and the mouth of the wicked devoureth iniquity.

verseText: Judgments are prepared for scorners, and stripes for the back of fools.
mdText: Judgments are prepared for scorners, and stripes for the back of fools.

verseText: Wine is a mocker, strong drink is raging: and whosoever is deceived thereby is not wise.
mdText: Wine _is_ a mocker, strong drink _is_ raging: and whosoever is deceived thereby is not wise.

verseText: The fear of a king is as the roaring of a lion: whoso provoketh him to anger sinneth against his own soul.
mdText: The fear of a king _is_ as the roaring of a lion: _whoso_ provoketh him to anger sinneth _against_ his own soul.

verseText: It is an honour for a man to cease from strife: but every fool will be meddling.
mdText: _It_ _is_ an honour for a man to cease from strife: but every fool will be meddling.

verseText: The sluggard will not plow by reason of the cold; therefore shall he beg in harvest, and have nothing.
mdText: The sluggard will not plow by reason of the cold; _therefore_ shall he beg in harvest, and _have_ nothing.

verseText: Counsel in the heart of man is like deep water; but a man of understanding will draw it out.
mdText: Counsel in the heart of man _is_ _like_ deep water; but a man of understanding will draw it out.

verseText: Most men will proclaim every one his own goodness: but a faithful man who can find?
mdText: Most men will proclaim every one his own goodness: but a faithful man who can find?

verseText: The just man walketh in his integrity: his children are blessed after him.
mdText: The just _man_ walketh in his integrity: his children _are_ blessed after him.

verseText: A king that sitteth in the throne of judgment scattereth away all evil with his eyes.
mdText: A king that sitteth in the throne of judgment scattereth away all evil with his eyes.

verseText: Who can say, I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin?
mdText: Who can say, I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin?

verseText: Divers weights, and divers measures, both of them are alike abomination to the LORD.
mdText: Divers weights, _and_ divers measures, both of them _are_ alike abomination to the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: Even a child is known by his doings, whether his work be pure, and whether it be right.
mdText: Even a child is known by his doings, whether his work _be_ pure, and whether _it_ _be_ right.

verseText: The hearing ear, and the seeing eye, the LORD hath made even both of them.
mdText: The hearing ear, and the seeing eye, the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) hath made even both of them.

verseText: Love not sleep, lest thou come to poverty; open thine eyes, and thou shalt be satisfied with bread.
mdText: Love not sleep, lest thou come to poverty; open thine eyes, _and_ thou shalt be satisfied with bread.

verseText: It is naught, it is naught, saith the buyer: but when he is gone his way, then he boasteth.
mdText: _It_ _is_ naught, _it_ _is_ naught, saith the buyer: but when he is gone his way, then he boasteth.

verseText: There is gold, and a multitude of rubies: but the lips of knowledge are a precious jewel.
mdText: There is gold, and a multitude of rubies: but the lips of knowledge _are_ a precious jewel.

verseText: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger: and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.
mdText: Take his garment that is surety _for_ a stranger: and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.

verseText: Bread of deceit is sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.
mdText: Bread of deceit _is_ sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.

verseText: Every purpose is established by counsel: and with good advice make war.
mdText: _Every_ purpose is established by counsel: and with good advice make war.

verseText: He that goeth about as a talebearer revealeth secrets: therefore meddle not with him that flattereth with his lips.
mdText: He that goeth about _as_ a talebearer revealeth secrets: therefore meddle not with him that flattereth with his lips.

verseText: Whoso curseth his father or his mother, his lamp shall be put out in obscure darkness.
mdText: Whoso curseth his father or his mother, his lamp shall be put out in obscure darkness.

verseText: An inheritance may be gotten hastily at the beginning; but the end thereof shall not be blessed.
mdText: An inheritance _may_ _be_ gotten hastily at the beginning; but the end thereof shall not be blessed.

verseText: Say not thou, I will recompense evil; but wait on the LORD, and he shall save thee.
mdText: Say not thou, I will recompense evil; _but_ wait on the [LORD,]([/person/god_1324) and he shall save thee.

verseText: Divers weights are an abomination unto the LORD; and a false balance is not good.
mdText: Divers weights _are_ an abomination unto the [LORD;]([/person/god_1324) and a false balance _is_ not good.

verseText: Man’s goings are of the LORD; how can a man then understand his own way?
mdText: Man’s goings _are_ of the [LORD;]([/person/god_1324) how can a man then understand his own way?

verseText: It is a snare to the man who devoureth that which is holy, and after vows to make enquiry.
mdText: _It_ _is_ a snare to the man _who_ devoureth _that_ _which_ _is_ holy, and after vows to make enquiry.

verseText: A wise king scattereth the wicked, and bringeth the wheel over them.
mdText: A wise king scattereth the wicked, and bringeth the wheel over them.

verseText: The spirit of man is the candle of the LORD, searching all the inward parts of the belly.
mdText: The spirit of man _is_ the candle of the [LORD,]([/person/god_1324) searching all the inward parts of the belly.

verseText: Mercy and truth preserve the king: and his throne is upholden by mercy.
mdText: Mercy and truth preserve the king: and his throne is upholden by mercy.

verseText: The glory of young men is their strength: and the beauty of old men is the gray head.
mdText: The glory of young men _is_ their strength: and the beauty of old men _is_ the gray head.

verseText: The blueness of a wound cleanseth away evil: so do stripes the inward parts of the belly.
mdText: The blueness of a wound cleanseth away evil: so _do_ stripes the inward parts of the belly.

verseText: The king’s heart is in the hand of the LORD, as the rivers of water: he turneth it whithersoever he will.
mdText: The king’s heart _is_ in the hand of the [LORD,]([/person/god_1324) _as_ the rivers of water: he turneth it whithersoever he will.

verseText: Every way of a man is right in his own eyes: but the LORD pondereth the hearts.
mdText: Every way of a man _is_ right in his own eyes: but the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) pondereth the hearts.

verseText: To do justice and judgment is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.
mdText: To do justice and judgment _is_ more acceptable to the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) than sacrifice.

verseText: An high look, and a proud heart, and the plowing of the wicked, is sin.
mdText: An high look, and a proud heart, _and_ the plowing of the wicked, _is_ sin.

verseText: The thoughts of the diligent tend only to plenteousness; but of every one that is hasty only to want.
mdText: The thoughts of the diligent _tend_ only to plenteousness; but of every one _that_ _is_ hasty only to want.

verseText: The getting of treasures by a lying tongue is a vanity tossed to and fro of them that seek death.
mdText: The getting of treasures by a lying tongue _is_ a vanity tossed to and fro of them that seek death.

verseText: The robbery of the wicked shall destroy them; because they refuse to do judgment.
mdText: The robbery of the wicked shall destroy them; because they refuse to do judgment.

verseText: The way of man is froward and strange: but as for the pure, his work is right.
mdText: The way of man _is_ froward and strange: but _as_ _for_ the pure, his work _is_ right.

verseText: It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop, than with a brawling woman in a wide house.
mdText: _It_ _is_ better to dwell in a corner of the housetop, than with a brawling woman in a wide house.

verseText: The soul of the wicked desireth evil: his neighbour findeth no favour in his eyes.
mdText: The soul of the wicked desireth evil: his neighbour findeth no favour in his eyes.

verseText: When the scorner is punished, the simple is made wise: and when the wise is instructed, he receiveth knowledge.
mdText: When the scorner is punished, the simple is made wise: and when the wise is instructed, he receiveth knowledge.

verseText: The righteous man wisely considereth the house of the wicked: but God overthroweth the wicked for their wickedness.
mdText: The righteous _man_ wisely considereth the house of the wicked: _but_ _[God]([/person/god_1324)_ overthroweth the wicked for _their_ wickedness.

verseText: Whoso stoppeth his ears at the cry of the poor, he also shall cry himself, but shall not be heard.
mdText: Whoso stoppeth his ears at the cry of the poor, he also shall cry himself, but shall not be heard.

verseText: A gift in secret pacifieth anger: and a reward in the bosom strong wrath.
mdText: A gift in secret pacifieth anger: and a reward in the bosom strong wrath.

verseText: It is joy to the just to do judgment: but destruction shall be to the workers of iniquity.
mdText: _It_ _is_ joy to the just to do judgment: but destruction _shall_ _be_ to the workers of iniquity.

verseText: The man that wandereth out of the way of understanding shall remain in the congregation of the dead.
mdText: The man that wandereth out of the way of understanding shall remain in the congregation of the dead.

verseText: He that loveth pleasure shall be a poor man: he that loveth wine and oil shall not be rich.
mdText: He that loveth pleasure _shall_ _be_ a poor man: he that loveth wine and oil shall not be rich.

verseText: The wicked shall be a ransom for the righteous, and the transgressor for the upright.
mdText: The wicked _shall_ _be_ a ransom for the righteous, and the transgressor for the upright.

verseText: It is better to dwell in the wilderness, than with a contentious and an angry woman.
mdText: _It_ _is_ better to dwell in the wilderness, than with a contentious and an angry woman.

verseText: There is treasure to be desired and oil in the dwelling of the wise; but a foolish man spendeth it up.
mdText: _There_ _is_ treasure to be desired and oil in the dwelling of the wise; but a foolish man spendeth it up.

verseText: He that followeth after righteousness and mercy findeth life, righteousness, and honour.
mdText: He that followeth after righteousness and mercy findeth life, righteousness, and honour.

verseText: A wise man scaleth the city of the mighty, and casteth down the strength of the confidence thereof.
mdText: A wise _man_ scaleth the city of the mighty, and casteth down the strength of the confidence thereof.

verseText: Whoso keepeth his mouth and his tongue keepeth his soul from troubles.
mdText: Whoso keepeth his mouth and his tongue keepeth his soul from troubles.

verseText: Proud and haughty scorner is his name, who dealeth in proud wrath.
mdText: Proud _and_ haughty scorner _is_ his name, who dealeth in proud wrath.

verseText: The desire of the slothful killeth him; for his hands refuse to labour.
mdText: The desire of the slothful killeth him; for his hands refuse to labour.

verseText: He coveteth greedily all the day long: but the righteous giveth and spareth not.
mdText: He coveteth greedily all the day long: but the righteous giveth and spareth not.

verseText: The sacrifice of the wicked is abomination: how much more, when he bringeth it with a wicked mind?
mdText: The sacrifice of the wicked _is_ abomination: how much more, _when_ he bringeth it with a wicked mind?

verseText: A false witness shall perish: but the man that heareth speaketh constantly.
mdText: A false witness shall perish: but the man that heareth speaketh constantly.

verseText: A wicked man hardeneth his face: but as for the upright, he directeth his way.
mdText: A wicked man hardeneth his face: but _as_ _for_ the upright, he directeth his way.

verseText: There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the LORD.
mdText: _There_ _is_ no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: The horse is prepared against the day of battle: but safety is of the LORD.
mdText: The horse _is_ prepared against the day of battle: but safety _is_ of the [LORD.]([/person/god_1324)

verseText: A good name is rather to be chosen than great riches, and loving favour rather than silver and gold.
mdText: A _good_ name _is_ rather to be chosen than great riches, _and_ loving favour rather than silver and gold.

verseText: The rich and poor meet together: the LORD is the maker of them all.
mdText: The rich and poor meet together: the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) _is_ the maker of them all.

verseText: A prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself: but the simple pass on, and are punished.
mdText: A prudent _man_ foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself: but the simple pass on, and are punished.

verseText: By humility and the fear of the LORD are riches, and honour, and life.
mdText: By humility _and_ the fear of the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) _are_ riches, and honour, and life.

verseText: Thorns and snares are in the way of the froward: he that doth keep his soul shall be far from them.
mdText: Thorns _and_ snares _are_ in the way of the froward: he that doth keep his soul shall be far from them.

verseText: Train up a child in the way he should go: and when he is old, he will not depart from it.
mdText: Train up a child in the way he should go: and when he is old, he will not depart from it.

verseText: The rich ruleth over the poor, and the borrower is servant to the lender.
mdText: The rich ruleth over the poor, and the borrower _is_ servant to the lender.

verseText: He that soweth iniquity shall reap vanity: and the rod of his anger shall fail.
mdText: He that soweth iniquity shall reap vanity: and the rod of his anger shall fail.

verseText: He that hath a bountiful eye shall be blessed; for he giveth of his bread to the poor.
mdText: He that hath a bountiful eye shall be blessed; for he giveth of his bread to the poor.

verseText: Cast out the scorner, and contention shall go out; yea, strife and reproach shall cease.
mdText: Cast out the scorner, and contention shall go out; yea, strife and reproach shall cease.

verseText: He that loveth pureness of heart, for the grace of his lips the king shall be his friend.
mdText: He that loveth pureness of heart, _for_ the grace of his lips the king _shall_ _be_ his friend.

verseText: The eyes of the LORD preserve knowledge, and he overthroweth the words of the transgressor.
mdText: The eyes of the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) preserve knowledge, and he overthroweth the words of the transgressor.

verseText: The slothful man saith, There is a lion without, I shall be slain in the streets.
mdText: The slothful _man_ saith, _There_ _is_ a lion without, I shall be slain in the streets.

verseText: The mouth of strange women is a deep pit: he that is abhorred of the LORD shall fall therein.
mdText: The mouth of strange women _is_ a deep pit: he that is abhorred of the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) shall fall therein.

verseText: Foolishness is bound in the heart of a child; but the rod of correction shall drive it far from him.
mdText: Foolishness _is_ bound in the heart of a child; _but_ the rod of correction shall drive it far from him.

verseText: He that oppresseth the poor to increase his riches, and he that giveth to the rich, shall surely come to want.
mdText: He that oppresseth the poor to increase his _riches,_ _and_ he that giveth to the rich, _shall_ surely _come_ to want.

verseText: Bow down thine ear, and hear the words of the wise, and apply thine heart unto my knowledge.
mdText: Bow down thine ear, and hear the words of the wise, and apply thine heart unto my knowledge.

verseText: For it is a pleasant thing if thou keep them within thee; they shall withal be fitted in thy lips.
mdText: For _it_ _is_ a pleasant thing if thou keep them within thee; they shall withal be fitted in thy lips.

verseText: That thy trust may be in the LORD, I have made known to thee this day, even to thee.
mdText: That thy trust may be in the [LORD,]([/person/god_1324) I have made known to thee this day, even to thee.

verseText: Have not I written to thee excellent things in counsels and knowledge,
mdText: Have not I written to thee excellent things in counsels and knowledge,

verseText: That I might make thee know the certainty of the words of truth; that thou mightest answer the words of truth to them that send unto thee?
mdText: That I might make thee know the certainty of the words of truth; that thou mightest answer the words of truth to them that send unto thee?

verseText: Rob not the poor, because he is poor: neither oppress the afflicted in the gate:
mdText: Rob not the poor, because he _is_ poor: neither oppress the afflicted in the gate:

verseText: For the LORD will plead their cause, and spoil the soul of those that spoiled them.
mdText: For the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) will plead their cause, and spoil the soul of those that spoiled them.

verseText: Make no friendship with an angry man; and with a furious man thou shalt not go:
mdText: Make no friendship with an angry man; and with a furious man thou shalt not go:

verseText: Lest thou learn his ways, and get a snare to thy soul.
mdText: Lest thou learn his ways, and get a snare to thy soul.

verseText: Be not thou one of them that strike hands, or of them that are sureties for debts.
mdText: Be not thou _one_ of them that strike hands, _or_ of them that are sureties for debts.

verseText: If thou hast nothing to pay, why should he take away thy bed from under thee?
mdText: If thou hast nothing to pay, why should he take away thy bed from under thee?

verseText: Remove not the ancient landmark, which thy fathers have set.
mdText: Remove not the ancient landmark, which thy fathers have set.

verseText: Seest thou a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings; he shall not stand before mean men.
mdText: Seest thou a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings; he shall not stand before mean _men._

verseText: When thou sittest to eat with a ruler, consider diligently what is before thee:
mdText: When thou sittest to eat with a ruler, consider diligently what _is_ before thee:

verseText: And put a knife to thy throat, if thou be a man given to appetite.
mdText: And put a knife to thy throat, if thou _be_ a man given to appetite.

verseText: Be not desirous of his dainties: for they are deceitful meat.
mdText: Be not desirous of his dainties: for they _are_ deceitful meat.

verseText: Labour not to be rich: cease from thine own wisdom.
mdText: Labour not to be rich: cease from thine own wisdom.

verseText: Wilt thou set thine eyes upon that which is not? for riches certainly make themselves wings; they fly away as an eagle toward heaven.
mdText: Wilt thou set thine eyes upon that which is not? for _riches_ certainly make themselves wings; they fly away as an eagle toward heaven.

verseText: Eat thou not the bread of him that hath an evil eye, neither desire thou his dainty meats:
mdText: Eat thou not the bread of _him_ _that_ _hath_ an evil eye, neither desire thou his dainty meats:

verseText: For as he thinketh in his heart, so is he: Eat and drink, saith he to thee; but his heart is not with thee.
mdText: For as he thinketh in his heart, so _is_ he: Eat and drink, saith he to thee; but his heart _is_ not with thee.

verseText: The morsel which thou hast eaten shalt thou vomit up, and lose thy sweet words.
mdText: The morsel _which_ thou hast eaten shalt thou vomit up, and lose thy sweet words.

verseText: Speak not in the ears of a fool: for he will despise the wisdom of thy words.
mdText: Speak not in the ears of a fool: for he will despise the wisdom of thy words.

verseText: Remove not the old landmark; and enter not into the fields of the fatherless:
mdText: Remove not the old landmark; and enter not into the fields of the fatherless:

verseText: For their redeemer is mighty; he shall plead their cause with thee.
mdText: For their redeemer _is_ mighty; he shall plead their cause with thee.

verseText: Apply thine heart unto instruction, and thine ears to the words of knowledge.
mdText: Apply thine heart unto instruction, and thine ears to the words of knowledge.

verseText: Withhold not correction from the child: for if thou beatest him with the rod, he shall not die.
mdText: Withhold not correction from the child: for _if_ thou beatest him with the rod, he shall not die.

verseText: Thou shalt beat him with the rod, and shalt deliver his soul from hell.
mdText: Thou shalt beat him with the rod, and shalt deliver his soul from hell.

verseText: My son, if thine heart be wise, my heart shall rejoice, even mine.
mdText: My son, if thine heart be wise, my heart shall rejoice, even mine.

verseText: Yea, my reins shall rejoice, when thy lips speak right things.
mdText: Yea, my reins shall rejoice, when thy lips speak right things.

verseText: Let not thine heart envy sinners: but be thou in the fear of the LORD all the day long.
mdText: Let not thine heart envy sinners: but _be_ _thou_ in the fear of the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) all the day long.

verseText: For surely there is an end; and thine expectation shall not be cut off.
mdText: For surely there is an end; and thine expectation shall not be cut off.

verseText: Hear thou, my son, and be wise, and guide thine heart in the way.
mdText: Hear thou, my son, and be wise, and guide thine heart in the way.

verseText: Be not among winebibbers; among riotous eaters of flesh:
mdText: Be not among winebibbers; among riotous eaters of flesh:

verseText: For the drunkard and the glutton shall come to poverty: and drowsiness shall clothe a man with rags.
mdText: For the drunkard and the glutton shall come to poverty: and drowsiness shall clothe _a_ _man_ with rags.

verseText: Hearken unto thy father that begat thee, and despise not thy mother when she is old.
mdText: Hearken unto thy father that begat thee, and despise not thy mother when she is old.

verseText: Buy the truth, and sell it not; also wisdom, and instruction, and understanding.
mdText: Buy the truth, and sell _it_ not; _also_ wisdom, and instruction, and understanding.

verseText: The father of the righteous shall greatly rejoice: and he that begetteth a wise child shall have joy of him.
mdText: The father of the righteous shall greatly rejoice: and he that begetteth a wise _child_ shall have joy of him.

verseText: Thy father and thy mother shall be glad, and she that bare thee shall rejoice.
mdText: Thy father and thy mother shall be glad, and she that bare thee shall rejoice.

verseText: My son, give me thine heart, and let thine eyes observe my ways.
mdText: My son, give me thine heart, and let thine eyes observe my ways.

verseText: For a whore is a deep ditch; and a strange woman is a narrow pit.
mdText: For a whore _is_ a deep ditch; and a strange woman _is_ a narrow pit.

verseText: She also lieth in wait as for a prey, and increaseth the transgressors among men.
mdText: She also lieth in wait as _for_ a prey, and increaseth the transgressors among men.

verseText: Who hath woe? who hath sorrow? who hath contentions? who hath babbling? who hath wounds without cause? who hath redness of eyes?
mdText: Who hath woe? who hath sorrow? who hath contentions? who hath babbling? who hath wounds without cause? who hath redness of eyes?

verseText: They that tarry long at the wine; they that go to seek mixed wine.
mdText: They that tarry long at the wine; they that go to seek mixed wine.

verseText: Look not thou upon the wine when it is red, when it giveth his colour in the cup, when it moveth itself aright.
mdText: Look not thou upon the wine when it is red, when it giveth his colour in the cup, _when_ it moveth itself aright.

verseText: At the last it biteth like a serpent, and stingeth like an adder.
mdText: At the last it biteth like a serpent, and stingeth like an adder.

verseText: Thine eyes shall behold strange women, and thine heart shall utter perverse things.
mdText: Thine eyes shall behold strange women, and thine heart shall utter perverse things.

verseText: Yea, thou shalt be as he that lieth down in the midst of the sea, or as he that lieth upon the top of a mast.
mdText: Yea, thou shalt be as he that lieth down in the midst of the sea, or as he that lieth upon the top of a mast.

verseText: They have stricken me, shalt thou say, and I was not sick; they have beaten me, and I felt it not: when shall I awake? I will seek it yet again.
mdText: They have stricken me, _shalt_ _thou_ _say,_ _and_ I was not sick; they have beaten me, _and_ I felt _it_ not: when shall I awake? I will seek it yet again.

verseText: Be not thou envious against evil men, neither desire to be with them.
mdText: Be not thou envious against evil men, neither desire to be with them.

verseText: For their heart studieth destruction, and their lips talk of mischief.
mdText: For their heart studieth destruction, and their lips talk of mischief.

verseText: Through wisdom is an house builded; and by understanding it is established:
mdText: Through wisdom is an house builded; and by understanding it is established:

verseText: And by knowledge shall the chambers be filled with all precious and pleasant riches.
mdText: And by knowledge shall the chambers be filled with all precious and pleasant riches.

verseText: A wise man is strong; yea, a man of knowledge increaseth strength.
mdText: A wise man _is_ strong; yea, a man of knowledge increaseth strength.

verseText: For by wise counsel thou shalt make thy war: and in multitude of counsellors there is safety.
mdText: For by wise counsel thou shalt make thy war: and in multitude of counsellors _there_ _is_ safety.

verseText: Wisdom is too high for a fool: he openeth not his mouth in the gate.
mdText: Wisdom _is_ too high for a fool: he openeth not his mouth in the gate.

verseText: He that deviseth to do evil shall be called a mischievous person.
mdText: He that deviseth to do evil shall be called a mischievous person.

verseText: The thought of foolishness is sin: and the scorner is an abomination to men.
mdText: The thought of foolishness _is_ sin: and the scorner _is_ an abomination to men.

verseText: If thou faint in the day of adversity, thy strength is small.
mdText: _If_ thou faint in the day of adversity, thy strength _is_ small.

verseText: If thou forbear to deliver them that are drawn unto death, and those that are ready to be slain;
mdText: If thou forbear to deliver _them_ _that_ _are_ drawn unto death, and _those_ _that_ _are_ ready to be slain;

verseText: If thou sayest, Behold, we knew it not; doth not he that pondereth the heart consider it? and he that keepeth thy soul, doth not he know it? and shall not he render to every man according to his works?
mdText: If thou sayest, Behold, we knew it not; doth not he that pondereth the heart consider _it?_ and he that keepeth thy soul, doth _not_ he know _it?_ and shall _not_ he render to _every_ man according to his works?

verseText: My son, eat thou honey, because it is good; and the honeycomb, which is sweet to thy taste:
mdText: My son, eat thou honey, because _it_ _is_ good; and the honeycomb, _which_ _is_ sweet to thy taste:

verseText: So shall the knowledge of wisdom be unto thy soul: when thou hast found it, then there shall be a reward, and thy expectation shall not be cut off.
mdText: So _shall_ the knowledge of wisdom _be_ unto thy soul: when thou hast found _it,_ then there shall be a reward, and thy expectation shall not be cut off.

verseText: Lay not wait, O wicked man, against the dwelling of the righteous; spoil not his resting place:
mdText: Lay not wait, O wicked _man,_ against the dwelling of the righteous; spoil not his resting place:

verseText: For a just man falleth seven times, and riseth up again: but the wicked shall fall into mischief.
mdText: For a just _man_ falleth seven times, and riseth up again: but the wicked shall fall into mischief.

verseText: Rejoice not when thine enemy falleth, and let not thine heart be glad when he stumbleth:
mdText: Rejoice not when thine enemy falleth, and let not thine heart be glad when he stumbleth:

verseText: Lest the LORD see it, and it displease him, and he turn away his wrath from him.
mdText: Lest the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) see _it,_ and it displease him, and he turn away his wrath from him.

verseText: Fret not thyself because of evil men, neither be thou envious at the wicked;
mdText: Fret not thyself because of evil _men,_ neither be thou envious at the wicked;

verseText: For there shall be no reward to the evil man; the candle of the wicked shall be put out.
mdText: For there shall be no reward to the evil _man;_ the candle of the wicked shall be put out.

verseText: My son, fear thou the LORD and the king: and meddle not with them that are given to change:
mdText: My son, fear thou the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) and the king: _and_ meddle not with them that are given to change:

verseText: For their calamity shall rise suddenly; and who knoweth the ruin of them both?
mdText: For their calamity shall rise suddenly; and who knoweth the ruin of them both?

verseText: These things also belong to the wise. It is not good to have respect of persons in judgment.
mdText: These _things_ also _belong_ to the wise. _It_ _is_ not good to have respect of persons in judgment.

verseText: He that saith unto the wicked, Thou art righteous; him shall the people curse, nations shall abhor him:
mdText: He that saith unto the wicked, Thou _art_ righteous; him shall the people curse, nations shall abhor him:

verseText: But to them that rebuke him shall be delight, and a good blessing shall come upon them.
mdText: But to them that rebuke _him_ shall be delight, and a good blessing shall come upon them.

verseText: Every man shall kiss his lips that giveth a right answer.
mdText: _Every_ _man_ shall kiss _his_ lips that giveth a right answer.

verseText: Prepare thy work without, and make it fit for thyself in the field; and afterwards build thine house.
mdText: Prepare thy work without, and make it fit for thyself in the field; and afterwards build thine house.

verseText: Be not a witness against thy neighbour without cause; and deceive not with thy lips.
mdText: Be not a witness against thy neighbour without cause; and deceive _not_ with thy lips.

verseText: Say not, I will do so to him as he hath done to me: I will render to the man according to his work.
mdText: Say not, I will do so to him as he hath done to me: I will render to the man according to his work.

verseText: I went by the field of the slothful, and by the vineyard of the man void of understanding;
mdText: I went by the field of the slothful, and by the vineyard of the man void of understanding;

verseText: And, lo, it was all grown over with thorns, and nettles had covered the face thereof, and the stone wall thereof was broken down.
mdText: And, lo, it was all grown over with thorns, _and_ nettles had covered the face thereof, and the stone wall thereof was broken down.

verseText: Then I saw, and considered it well: I looked upon it, and received instruction.
mdText: Then I saw, _and_ considered _it_ well: I looked upon _it,_ _and_ received instruction.

verseText: Yet a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to sleep:
mdText: _Yet_ a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to sleep:

verseText: So shall thy poverty come as one that travelleth; and thy want as an armed man.
mdText: So shall thy poverty come _as_ one that travelleth; and thy want as an armed man.

verseText: These are also proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out.
mdText: These _are_ also proverbs of [Solomon,]([/person/solomon_2762) which the men of [Hezekiah]([/person/hezekiah_1512) king of Judah copied out.

verseText: It is the glory of God to conceal a thing: but the honour of kings is to search out a matter.
mdText: _It_ _is_ the glory of [God]([/person/god_1324) to conceal a thing: but the honour of kings _is_ to search out a matter.

verseText: The heaven for height, and the earth for depth, and the heart of kings is unsearchable.
mdText: The heaven for height, and the earth for depth, and the heart of kings _is_ unsearchable.

verseText: Take away the dross from the silver, and there shall come forth a vessel for the finer.
mdText: Take away the dross from the silver, and there shall come forth a vessel for the finer.

verseText: Take away the wicked from before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.
mdText: Take away the wicked _from_ before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.

verseText: Put not forth thyself in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great men:
mdText: Put not forth thyself in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great _men:_

verseText: For better it is that it be said unto thee, Come up hither; than that thou shouldest be put lower in the presence of the prince whom thine eyes have seen.
mdText: For better _it_ _is_ that it be said unto thee, Come up hither; than that thou shouldest be put lower in the presence of the prince whom thine eyes have seen.

verseText: Go not forth hastily to strive, lest thou know not what to do in the end thereof, when thy neighbour hath put thee to shame.
mdText: Go not forth hastily to strive, lest _thou_ _know_ _not_ what to do in the end thereof, when thy neighbour hath put thee to shame.

verseText: Debate thy cause with thy neighbour himself; and discover not a secret to another:
mdText: Debate thy cause with thy neighbour _himself;_ and discover not a secret to another:

verseText: Lest he that heareth it put thee to shame, and thine infamy turn not away.
mdText: Lest he that heareth _it_ put thee to shame, and thine infamy turn not away.

verseText: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in pictures of silver.
mdText: A word fitly spoken _is_ _like_ apples of gold in pictures of silver.

verseText: As an earring of gold, and an ornament of fine gold, so is a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.
mdText: _As_ an earring of gold, and an ornament of fine gold, _so_ _is_ a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.

verseText: As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, so is a faithful messenger to them that send him: for he refresheth the soul of his masters.
mdText: As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, _so_ _is_ a faithful messenger to them that send him: for he refresheth the soul of his masters.

verseText: Whoso boasteth himself of a false gift is like clouds and wind without rain.
mdText: Whoso boasteth himself of a false gift _is_ _like_ clouds and wind without rain.

verseText: By long forbearing is a prince persuaded, and a soft tongue breaketh the bone.
mdText: By long forbearing is a prince persuaded, and a soft tongue breaketh the bone.

verseText: Hast thou found honey? eat so much as is sufficient for thee, lest thou be filled therewith, and vomit it.
mdText: Hast thou found honey? eat so much as is sufficient for thee, lest thou be filled therewith, and vomit it.

verseText: Withdraw thy foot from thy neighbour’s house; lest he be weary of thee, and so hate thee.
mdText: Withdraw thy foot from thy neighbour’s house; lest he be weary of thee, and _so_ hate thee.

verseText: A man that beareth false witness against his neighbour is a maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow.
mdText: A man that beareth false witness against his neighbour _is_ a maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow.

verseText: Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble is like a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.
mdText: Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble _is_ _like_ a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.

verseText: As he that taketh away a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar upon nitre, so is he that singeth songs to an heavy heart.
mdText: _As_ he that taketh away a garment in cold weather, _and_ _as_ vinegar upon nitre, so _is_ he that singeth songs to an heavy heart.

verseText: If thine enemy be hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he be thirsty, give him water to drink:
mdText: If thine enemy be hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he be thirsty, give him water to drink:

verseText: For thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the LORD shall reward thee.
mdText: For thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) shall reward thee.

verseText: The north wind driveth away rain: so doth an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.
mdText: The north wind driveth away rain: so _doth_ an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.

verseText: It is better to dwell in the corner of the housetop, than with a brawling woman and in a wide house.
mdText: _It_ _is_ better to dwell in the corner of the housetop, than with a brawling woman and in a wide house.

verseText: As cold waters to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a far country.
mdText: _As_ cold waters to a thirsty soul, so _is_ good news from a far country.

verseText: A righteous man falling down before the wicked is as a troubled fountain, and a corrupt spring.
mdText: A righteous man falling down before the wicked _is_ _as_ a troubled fountain, and a corrupt spring.

verseText: It is not good to eat much honey: so for men to search their own glory is not glory.
mdText: _It_ _is_ not good to eat much honey: so _for_ _men_ to search their own glory _is_ _not_ glory.

verseText: He that hath no rule over his own spirit is like a city that is broken down, and without walls.
mdText: He that _hath_ no rule over his own spirit _is_ _like_ a city _that_ _is_ broken down, _and_ without walls.

verseText: As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honour is not seemly for a fool.
mdText: As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honour is not seemly for a fool.

verseText: As the bird by wandering, as the swallow by flying, so the curse causeless shall not come.
mdText: As the bird by wandering, as the swallow by flying, so the curse causeless shall not come.

verseText: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the fool’s back.
mdText: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the fool’s back.

verseText: Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like unto him.
mdText: Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like unto him.

verseText: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own conceit.
mdText: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own conceit.

verseText: He that sendeth a message by the hand of a fool cutteth off the feet, and drinketh damage.
mdText: He that sendeth a message by the hand of a fool cutteth off the feet, _and_ drinketh damage.

verseText: The legs of the lame are not equal: so is a parable in the mouth of fools.
mdText: The legs of the lame are not equal: so _is_ a parable in the mouth of fools.

verseText: As he that bindeth a stone in a sling, so is he that giveth honour to a fool.
mdText: As he that bindeth a stone in a sling, so _is_ he that giveth honour to a fool.

verseText: As a thorn goeth up into the hand of a drunkard, so is a parable in the mouth of fools.
mdText: _As_ a thorn goeth up into the hand of a drunkard, so _is_ a parable in the mouth of fools.

verseText: The great God that formed all things both rewardeth the fool, and rewardeth transgressors.
mdText: The great _[God]([/person/god_1324)_ that formed all _things_ both rewardeth the fool, and rewardeth transgressors.

verseText: As a dog returneth to his vomit, so a fool returneth to his folly.
mdText: As a dog returneth to his vomit, _so_ a fool returneth to his folly.

verseText: Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? there is more hope of a fool than of him.
mdText: Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? _there_ _is_ more hope of a fool than of him.

verseText: The slothful man saith, There is a lion in the way; a lion is in the streets.
mdText: The slothful _man_ saith, _There_ _is_ a lion in the way; a lion _is_ in the streets.

verseText: As the door turneth upon his hinges, so doth the slothful upon his bed.
mdText: _As_ the door turneth upon his hinges, so _doth_ the slothful upon his bed.

verseText: The slothful hideth his hand in his bosom; it grieveth him to bring it again to his mouth.
mdText: The slothful hideth his hand in _his_ bosom; it grieveth him to bring it again to his mouth.

verseText: The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit than seven men that can render a reason.
mdText: The sluggard _is_ wiser in his own conceit than seven men that can render a reason.

verseText: He that passeth by, and meddleth with strife belonging not to him, is like one that taketh a dog by the ears.
mdText: He that passeth by, _and_ meddleth with strife _belonging_ not to him, _is_ _like_ one that taketh a dog by the ears.

verseText: As a mad man who casteth firebrands, arrows, and death,
mdText: As a mad _man_ who casteth firebrands, arrows, and death,

verseText: So is the man that deceiveth his neighbour, and saith, Am not I in sport?
mdText: So _is_ the man _that_ deceiveth his neighbour, and saith, Am not I in sport?

verseText: Where no wood is, there the fire goeth out: so where there is no talebearer, the strife ceaseth.
mdText: Where no wood is, _there_ the fire goeth out: so where _there_ _is_ no talebearer, the strife ceaseth.

verseText: As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire; so is a contentious man to kindle strife.
mdText: _As_ coals _are_ to burning coals, and wood to fire; so _is_ a contentious man to kindle strife.

verseText: The words of a talebearer are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
mdText: The words of a talebearer _are_ as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.

verseText: Burning lips and a wicked heart are like a potsherd covered with silver dross.
mdText: Burning lips and a wicked heart _are_ _like_ a potsherd covered with silver dross.

verseText: He that hateth dissembleth with his lips, and layeth up deceit within him;
mdText: He that hateth dissembleth with his lips, and layeth up deceit within him;

verseText: When he speaketh fair, believe him not: for there are seven abominations in his heart.
mdText: When he speaketh fair, believe him not: for _there_ _are_ seven abominations in his heart.

verseText: Whose hatred is covered by deceit, his wickedness shall be shewed before the whole congregation.
mdText: _Whose_ hatred is covered by deceit, his wickedness shall be shewed before the _whole_ congregation.

verseText: Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein: and he that rolleth a stone, it will return upon him.
mdText: Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein: and he that rolleth a stone, it will return upon him.

verseText: A lying tongue hateth those that are afflicted by it; and a flattering mouth worketh ruin.
mdText: A lying tongue hateth _those_ _that_ _are_ afflicted by it; and a flattering mouth worketh ruin.

verseText: Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.
mdText: Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.

verseText: Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.
mdText: Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.

verseText: A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool’s wrath is heavier than them both.
mdText: A stone _is_ heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool’s wrath _is_ heavier than them both.

verseText: Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who is able to stand before envy?
mdText: Wrath _is_ cruel, and anger _is_ outrageous; but who _is_ able to stand before envy?

verseText: Open rebuke is better than secret love.
mdText: Open rebuke _is_ better than secret love.

verseText: Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.
mdText: Faithful _are_ the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy _are_ deceitful.

verseText: The full soul loatheth an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
mdText: The full soul loatheth an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.

verseText: As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so is a man that wandereth from his place.
mdText: As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so _is_ a man that wandereth from his place.

verseText: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so doth the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.
mdText: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so _doth_ the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.

verseText: Thine own friend, and thy father’s friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother’s house in the day of thy calamity: for better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off.
mdText: Thine own friend, and thy father’s friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother’s house in the day of thy calamity: _for_ better _is_ a neighbour _that_ _is_ near than a brother far off.

verseText: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.
mdText: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.

verseText: A prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself; but the simple pass on, and are punished.
mdText: A prudent _man_ foreseeth the evil, _and_ hideth himself; _but_ the simple pass on, _and_ are punished.

verseText: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.
mdText: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.

verseText: He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.
mdText: He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.

verseText: A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.
mdText: A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.

verseText: Whosoever hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand, which bewrayeth itself.
mdText: Whosoever hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand, _which_ bewrayeth _itself._

verseText: Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.
mdText: Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.

verseText: Whoso keepeth the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.
mdText: Whoso keepeth the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.

verseText: As in water face answereth to face, so the heart of man to man.
mdText: As in water face _answereth_ to face, so the heart of man to man.

verseText: Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.
mdText: Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.

verseText: As the fining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a man to his praise.
mdText: _As_ the fining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so _is_ a man to his praise.

verseText: Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet will not his foolishness depart from him.
mdText: Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, _yet_ will not his foolishness depart from him.

verseText: Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, and look well to thy herds.
mdText: Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, _and_ look well to thy herds.

verseText: For riches are not for ever: and doth the crown endure to every generation?
mdText: For riches _are_ not for ever: and doth the crown _endure_ to every generation?

verseText: The hay appeareth, and the tender grass sheweth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.
mdText: The hay appeareth, and the tender grass sheweth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.

verseText: The lambs are for thy clothing, and the goats are the price of the field.
mdText: The lambs _are_ for thy clothing, and the goats _are_ the price of the field.

verseText: And thou shalt have goats’ milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and for the maintenance for thy maidens.
mdText: And _thou_ _shalt_ _have_ goats’ milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and _for_ the maintenance for thy maidens.

verseText: The wicked flee when no man pursueth: but the righteous are bold as a lion.
mdText: The wicked flee when no man pursueth: but the righteous are bold as a lion.

verseText: For the transgression of a land many are the princes thereof: but by a man of understanding and knowledge the state thereof shall be prolonged.
mdText: For the transgression of a land many _are_ the princes thereof: but by a man of understanding _and_ knowledge the state _thereof_ shall be prolonged.

verseText: A poor man that oppresseth the poor is like a sweeping rain which leaveth no food.
mdText: A poor man that oppresseth the poor _is_ _like_ a sweeping rain which leaveth no food.

verseText: They that forsake the law praise the wicked: but such as keep the law contend with them.
mdText: They that forsake the law praise the wicked: but such as keep the law contend with them.

verseText: Evil men understand not judgment: but they that seek the LORD understand all things.
mdText: Evil men understand not judgment: but they that seek the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) understand all _things._

verseText: Better is the poor that walketh in his uprightness, than he that is perverse in his ways, though he be rich.
mdText: Better _is_ the poor that walketh in his uprightness, than _he_ _that_ _is_ perverse _in_ _his_ ways, though he _be_ rich.

verseText: Whoso keepeth the law is a wise son: but he that is a companion of riotous men shameth his father.
mdText: Whoso keepeth the law _is_ a wise son: but he that is a companion of riotous _men_ shameth his father.

verseText: He that by usury and unjust gain increaseth his substance, he shall gather it for him that will pity the poor.
mdText: He that by usury and unjust gain increaseth his substance, he shall gather it for him that will pity the poor.

verseText: He that turneth away his ear from hearing the law, even his prayer shall be abomination.
mdText: He that turneth away his ear from hearing the law, even his prayer _shall_ _be_ abomination.

verseText: Whoso causeth the righteous to go astray in an evil way, he shall fall himself into his own pit: but the upright shall have good things in possession.
mdText: Whoso causeth the righteous to go astray in an evil way, he shall fall himself into his own pit: but the upright shall have good _things_ in possession.

verseText: The rich man is wise in his own conceit; but the poor that hath understanding searcheth him out.
mdText: The rich man _is_ wise in his own conceit; but the poor that hath understanding searcheth him out.

verseText: When righteous men do rejoice, there is great glory: but when the wicked rise, a man is hidden.
mdText: When righteous _men_ do rejoice, _there_ _is_ great glory: but when the wicked rise, a man is hidden.

verseText: He that covereth his sins shall not prosper: but whoso confesseth and forsaketh them shall have mercy.
mdText: He that covereth his sins shall not prosper: but whoso confesseth and forsaketh _them_ shall have mercy.

verseText: Happy is the man that feareth alway: but he that hardeneth his heart shall fall into mischief.
mdText: Happy _is_ the man that feareth alway: but he that hardeneth his heart shall fall into mischief.

verseText: As a roaring lion, and a ranging bear; so is a wicked ruler over the poor people.
mdText: _As_ a roaring lion, and a ranging bear; _so_ _is_ a wicked ruler over the poor people.

verseText: The prince that wanteth understanding is also a great oppressor: but he that hateth covetousness shall prolong his days.
mdText: The prince that wanteth understanding _is_ also a great oppressor: _but_ he that hateth covetousness shall prolong _his_ days.

verseText: A man that doeth violence to the blood of any person shall flee to the pit; let no man stay him.
mdText: A man that doeth violence to the blood of _any_ person shall flee to the pit; let no man stay him.

verseText: Whoso walketh uprightly shall be saved: but he that is perverse in his ways shall fall at once.
mdText: Whoso walketh uprightly shall be saved: but _he_ _that_ _is_ perverse _in_ _his_ ways shall fall at once.

verseText: He that tilleth his land shall have plenty of bread: but he that followeth after vain persons shall have poverty enough.
mdText: He that tilleth his land shall have plenty of bread: but he that followeth after vain _persons_ shall have poverty enough.

verseText: A faithful man shall abound with blessings: but he that maketh haste to be rich shall not be innocent.
mdText: A faithful man shall abound with blessings: but he that maketh haste to be rich shall not be innocent.

verseText: To have respect of persons is not good: for for a piece of bread that man will transgress.
mdText: To have respect of persons _is_ not good: for for a piece of bread _that_ man will transgress.

verseText: He that hasteth to be rich hath an evil eye, and considereth not that poverty shall come upon him.
mdText: He that hasteth to be rich _hath_ an evil eye, and considereth not that poverty shall come upon him.

verseText: He that rebuketh a man afterwards shall find more favour than he that flattereth with the tongue.
mdText: He that rebuketh a man afterwards shall find more favour than he that flattereth with the tongue.

verseText: Whoso robbeth his father or his mother, and saith, It is no transgression; the same is the companion of a destroyer.
mdText: Whoso robbeth his father or his mother, and saith, _It_ _is_ no transgression; the same _is_ the companion of a destroyer.

verseText: He that is of a proud heart stirreth up strife: but he that putteth his trust in the LORD shall be made fat.
mdText: He that is of a proud heart stirreth up strife: but he that putteth his trust in the [LORD]([/person/god_1324) shall be made fat.

verseText: He that trusteth in his own heart is a fool: but whoso walketh wisely, he shall be delivered.
mdText: He that trusteth in his own heart is a fool: but whoso walketh wisely, he shall be delivered.

verseText: He that giveth unto the poor shall not lack: but he that hideth his eyes shall have many a curse.
mdText: He that giveth unto the poor shall not lack: but he that hideth his eyes shall have many a curse.

verseText: When the wicked rise, men hide themselves: but when they perish, the righteous increase.
mdText: When the wicked rise, men hide themselves: but when they perish, the righteous increase.

verseText: He, that being often reproved hardeneth his neck, shall suddenly be destroyed, and that without remedy.
mdText: He, that being often reproved hardeneth _his_ neck, shall suddenly be destroyed, and that without remedy.

verseText: When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice: but when the wicked beareth rule, the people mourn.
mdText: When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice: but when the wicked beareth rule, the people mourn.

verseText: Whoso loveth wisdom rejoiceth his father: but he that keepeth company with harlots spendeth his substance.
mdText: Whoso loveth wisdom rejoiceth his father: but he that keepeth company with harlots spendeth _his_ substance.

verseText: The king by judgment establisheth the land: but he that receiveth gifts overthroweth it.
