verseText: Howbeit we must be cast upon a certain island.
mdText: Howbeit we must be cast upon a certain island.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: But when the fourteenth night was come, as we were driven up and down in Adria, about midnight the shipmen deemed that they drew near to some country;
mdText: But when the fourteenth night was come, as we were driven up and down in [Adria,](/place/adria_30) about midnight the shipmen deemed that they drew near to some country;
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And sounded, and found it twenty fathoms: and when they had gone a little further, they sounded again, and found it fifteen fathoms.
mdText: And sounded, and found _it_ twenty fathoms: and when they had gone a little further, they sounded again, and found _it_ fifteen fathoms.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: Then fearing lest we should have fallen upon rocks, they cast four anchors out of the stern, and wished for the day.
mdText: Then fearing lest we should have fallen upon rocks, they cast four anchors out of the stern, and wished for the day.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And as the shipmen were about to flee out of the ship, when they had let down the boat into the sea, under colour as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship,
mdText: And as the shipmen were about to flee out of the ship, when they had let down the boat into the sea, under colour as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship,
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be saved.
mdText: [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be saved.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat, and let her fall off.
mdText: Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat, and let her fall off.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And while the day was coming on, Paul besought them all to take meat, saying, This day is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried and continued fasting, having taken nothing.
mdText: And while the day was coming on, [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) besought _them_ all to take meat, saying, This day is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried and continued fasting, having taken nothing.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: Wherefore I pray you to take some meat: for this is for your health: for there shall not an hair fall from the head of any of you.
mdText: Wherefore I pray you to take _some_ meat: for this is for your health: for there shall not an hair fall from the head of any of you.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And when he had thus spoken, he took bread, and gave thanks to God in presence of them all: and when he had broken it, he began to eat.
mdText: And when he had thus spoken, he took bread, and gave thanks to [God]([/person/god_1324) in presence of them all: and when he had broken _it,_ he began to eat.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: Then were they all of good cheer, and they also took some meat.
mdText: Then were they all of good cheer, and they also took _some_ meat.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And we were in all in the ship two hundred threescore and sixteen souls.
mdText: And we were in all in the ship two hundred threescore and sixteen souls.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, and cast out the wheat into the sea.
mdText: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, and cast out the wheat into the sea.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And when it was day, they knew not the land: but they discovered a certain creek with a shore, into the which they were minded, if it were possible, to thrust in the ship.
mdText: And when it was day, they knew not the land: but they discovered a certain creek with a shore, into the which they were minded, if it were possible, to thrust in the ship.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed themselves unto the sea, and loosed the rudder bands, and hoised up the mainsail to the wind, and made toward shore.
mdText: And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed _themselves_ unto the sea, and loosed the rudder bands, and hoised up the mainsail to the wind, and made toward shore.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And falling into a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground; and the forepart stuck fast, and remained unmoveable, but the hinder part was broken with the violence of the waves.
mdText: And falling into a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground; and the forepart stuck fast, and remained unmoveable, but the hinder part was broken with the violence of the waves.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And the soldiers’ counsel was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim out, and escape.
mdText: And the soldiers’ counsel was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim out, and escape.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: But the centurion, willing to save Paul, kept them from their purpose; and commanded that they which could swim should cast themselves first into the sea, and get to land:
mdText: But the centurion, willing to save [Paul,]([/person/paul_2479) kept them from _their_ purpose; and commanded that they which could swim should cast _themselves_ first _into_ _the_ _sea,_ and get to land:
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And the rest, some on boards, and some on broken pieces of the ship. And so it came to pass, that they escaped all safe to land.
mdText: And the rest, some on boards, and some on _broken_ _pieces_ of the ship. And so it came to pass, that they escaped all safe to land.
eventsDescribed: Paul is shipwrecked by a storm

verseText: And when they were escaped, then they knew that the island was called Melita.
mdText: And when they were escaped, then they knew that the island was called [Melita.](/place/melita_761)

verseText: And the barbarous people shewed us no little kindness: for they kindled a fire, and received us every one, because of the present rain, and because of the cold.
mdText: And the barbarous people shewed us no little kindness: for they kindled a fire, and received us every one, because of the present rain, and because of the cold.

verseText: And when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks, and laid them on the fire, there came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand.
mdText: And when [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) had gathered a bundle of sticks, and laid _them_ on the fire, there came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand.

verseText: And when the barbarians saw the venomous beast hang on his hand, they said among themselves, No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he hath escaped the sea, yet vengeance suffereth not to live.
mdText: And when the barbarians saw the _venomous_ beast hang on his hand, they said among themselves, No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he hath escaped the sea, yet vengeance suffereth not to live.

verseText: And he shook off the beast into the fire, and felt no harm.
mdText: And he shook off the beast into the fire, and felt no harm.

verseText: Howbeit they looked when he should have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly: but after they had looked a great while, and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds, and said that he was a god.
mdText: Howbeit they looked when he should have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly: but after they had looked a great while, and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds, and said that he was a god.

verseText: In the same quarters were possessions of the chief man of the island, whose name was Publius; who received us, and lodged us three days courteously.
mdText: In the same quarters were possessions of the chief man of the island, whose name was [Publius;]([/person/publius_2374) who received us, and lodged us three days courteously.

verseText: And it came to pass, that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and of a bloody flux: to whom Paul entered in, and prayed, and laid his hands on him, and healed him.
mdText: And it came to pass, that the father of [Publius]([/person/publius_2374) lay sick of a fever and of a bloody flux: to whom [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) entered in, and prayed, and laid his hands on him, and healed him.

verseText: So when this was done, others also, which had diseases in the island, came, and were healed:
mdText: So when this was done, others also, which had diseases in the island, came, and were healed:

verseText: Who also honoured us with many honours; and when we departed, they laded us with such things as were necessary.
mdText: Who also honoured us with many honours; and when we departed, they laded _us_ with such things as were necessary.

verseText: And after three months we departed in a ship of Alexandria, which had wintered in the isle, whose sign was Castor and Pollux.
mdText: And after three months we departed in a ship of [Alexandria,](/place/alexandria_46) which had wintered in the isle, whose sign was Castor and Pollux.

verseText: And landing at Syracuse, we tarried there three days.
mdText: And landing at [Syracuse,](/place/syracuse_1121) we tarried _there_ three days.

verseText: And from thence we fetched a compass, and came to Rhegium: and after one day the south wind blew, and we came the next day to Puteoli:
mdText: And from thence we fetched a compass, and came to [Rhegium:](/place/rhegium_999) and after one day the south wind blew, and we came the next day to [Puteoli:](/place/puteoli_963)

verseText: Where we found brethren, and were desired to tarry with them seven days: and so we went toward Rome.
mdText: Where we found brethren, and were desired to tarry with them seven days: and so we went toward [Rome.](/place/rome_1013)

verseText: And from thence, when the brethren heard of us, they came to meet us as far as Appii forum, and The three taverns: whom when Paul saw, he thanked God, and took courage.
mdText: And from thence, when the brethren heard of us, they came to meet us as far as [Appii](/place/appii_forum_427) forum, and The three [taverns:](/place/three_taverns_1159) whom when [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) saw, he thanked [God,]([/person/god_1324) and took courage.

verseText: And when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard: but Paul was suffered to dwell by himself with a soldier that kept him.
mdText: And when we came to [Rome,](/place/rome_1013) the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard: but [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) was suffered to dwell by himself with a soldier that kept him.

verseText: And it came to pass, that after three days Paul called the chief of the Jews together: and when they were come together, he said unto them, Men and brethren, though I have committed nothing against the people, or customs of our fathers, yet was I delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
mdText: And it came to pass, that after three days [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) called the chief of the Jews together: and when they were come together, he said unto them, Men _and_ brethren, though I have committed nothing against the people, or customs of our fathers, yet was I delivered prisoner from [Jerusalem](/place/jerusalem_636) into the hands of the Romans.

verseText: Who, when they had examined me, would have let me go, because there was no cause of death in me.
mdText: Who, when they had examined me, would have let _me_ go, because there was no cause of death in me.

verseText: But when the Jews spake against it, I was constrained to appeal unto Caesar; not that I had ought to accuse my nation of.
mdText: But when the Jews spake against _it,_ I was constrained to appeal unto Caesar; not that I had ought to accuse my nation of.

verseText: For this cause therefore have I called for you, to see you, and to speak with you: because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
mdText: For this cause therefore have I called for you, to see _you,_ and to speak with _you:_ because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.

verseText: And they said unto him, We neither received letters out of Judaea concerning thee, neither any of the brethren that came shewed or spake any harm of thee.
mdText: And they said unto him, We neither received letters out of [Judaea](/place/judea_657) concerning thee, neither any of the brethren that came shewed or spake any harm of thee.

verseText: But we desire to hear of thee what thou thinkest: for as concerning this sect, we know that every where it is spoken against.
mdText: But we desire to hear of thee what thou thinkest: for as concerning this sect, we know that every where it is spoken against.

verseText: And when they had appointed him a day, there came many to him into his lodging; to whom he expounded and testified the kingdom of God, persuading them concerning Jesus, both out of the law of Moses, and out of the prophets, from morning till evening.
mdText: And when they had appointed him a day, there came many to him into _his_ lodging; to whom he expounded and testified the kingdom of [God,]([/person/god_1324) persuading them concerning [Jesus,]([/person/jesus_905) both out of the law of [Moses,]([/person/moses_2108) and _out_ _of_ the prophets, from morning till evening.

verseText: And some believed the things which were spoken, and some believed not.
mdText: And some believed the things which were spoken, and some believed not.

verseText: And when they agreed not among themselves, they departed, after that Paul had spoken one word, Well spake the Holy Ghost by Esaias the prophet unto our fathers,
mdText: And when they agreed not among themselves, they departed, after that [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) had spoken one word, Well spake the [Holy]([/person/holy_spirit_7400) Ghost by [Esaias]([/person/isaiah_617) the prophet unto our fathers,

verseText: Saying, Go unto this people, and say, Hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see, and not perceive:
mdText: Saying, Go unto this people, and say, Hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see, and not perceive:

verseText: For the heart of this people is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes have they closed; lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them.
mdText: For the heart of this people is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes have they closed; lest they should see with _their_ eyes, and hear with _their_ ears, and understand with _their_ heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them.

verseText: Be it known therefore unto you, that the salvation of God is sent unto the Gentiles, and that they will hear it.
mdText: Be it known therefore unto you, that the salvation of [God]([/person/god_1324) is sent unto the Gentiles, and _that_ they will hear it.

verseText: And when he had said these words, the Jews departed, and had great reasoning among themselves.
mdText: And when he had said these words, the Jews departed, and had great reasoning among themselves.

verseText: And Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house, and received all that came in unto him,
mdText: And [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) dwelt two whole years in his own hired house, and received all that came in unto him,

verseText: Preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ, with all confidence, no man forbidding him.
mdText: Preaching the kingdom of [God,]([/person/god_1324) and teaching those things which concern the [Lord]([/person/jesus_905) [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ,]([/person/jesus_905) with all confidence, no man forbidding him.

verseText: Paul, a servant of God, and an apostle of Jesus Christ, according to the faith of God’s elect, and the acknowledging of the truth which is after godliness;
mdText: [Paul,]([/person/paul_2479) a servant of [God,]([/person/god_1324) and an apostle of [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ,]([/person/jesus_905) according to the faith of [God’s]([/person/god_1324) elect, and the acknowledging of the truth which is after godliness;

verseText: In hope of eternal life, which God, that cannot lie, promised before the world began;
mdText: In hope of eternal life, which [God,]([/person/god_1324) that cannot lie, promised before the world began;

verseText: But hath in due times manifested his word through preaching, which is committed unto me according to the commandment of God our Saviour;
mdText: But hath in due times manifested his word through preaching, which is committed unto me according to the commandment of [God]([/person/god_1324) our [Saviour;]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: To Titus, mine own son after the common faith: Grace, mercy, and peace, from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ our Saviour.
mdText: To [Titus,]([/person/titus_2869) _mine_ own son after the common faith: Grace, mercy, _and_ peace, from [God]([/person/god_1324) the [Father]([/person/god_1324) and the [Lord]([/person/jesus_905) [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ]([/person/jesus_905) our [Saviour.]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: For this cause left I thee in Crete, that thou shouldest set in order the things that are wanting, and ordain elders in every city, as I had appointed thee:
mdText: For this cause left I thee in [Crete,](/place/crete_310) that thou shouldest set in order the things that are wanting, and ordain elders in every city, as I had appointed thee:

verseText: If any be blameless, the husband of one wife, having faithful children not accused of riot or unruly.
mdText: If any be blameless, the husband of one wife, having faithful children not accused of riot or unruly.

verseText: For a bishop must be blameless, as the steward of God; not selfwilled, not soon angry, not given to wine, no striker, not given to filthy lucre;
mdText: For a bishop must be blameless, as the steward of [God;]([/person/god_1324) not selfwilled, not soon angry, not given to wine, no striker, not given to filthy lucre;

verseText: But a lover of hospitality, a lover of good men, sober, just, holy, temperate;
mdText: But a lover of hospitality, a lover of good men, sober, just, holy, temperate;

verseText: Holding fast the faithful word as he hath been taught, that he may be able by sound doctrine both to exhort and to convince the gainsayers.
mdText: Holding fast the faithful word as he hath been taught, that he may be able by sound doctrine both to exhort and to convince the gainsayers.

verseText: For there are many unruly and vain talkers and deceivers, specially they of the circumcision:
mdText: For there are many unruly and vain talkers and deceivers, specially they of the circumcision:

verseText: Whose mouths must be stopped, who subvert whole houses, teaching things which they ought not, for filthy lucre’s sake.
mdText: Whose mouths must be stopped, who subvert whole houses, teaching things which they ought not, for filthy lucre’s sake.

verseText: One of themselves, even a prophet of their own, said, The Cretians are alway liars, evil beasts, slow bellies.
mdText: One of themselves, _even_ a prophet of their own, said, The Cretians _are_ alway liars, evil beasts, slow bellies.

verseText: This witness is true. Wherefore rebuke them sharply, that they may be sound in the faith;
mdText: This witness is true. Wherefore rebuke them sharply, that they may be sound in the faith;

verseText: Not giving heed to Jewish fables, and commandments of men, that turn from the truth.
mdText: Not giving heed to Jewish fables, and commandments of men, that turn from the truth.

verseText: Unto the pure all things are pure: but unto them that are defiled and unbelieving is nothing pure; but even their mind and conscience is defiled.
mdText: Unto the pure all things _are_ pure: but unto them that are defiled and unbelieving _is_ nothing pure; but even their mind and conscience is defiled.

verseText: They profess that they know God; but in works they deny him, being abominable, and disobedient, and unto every good work reprobate.
mdText: They profess that they know [God;]([/person/god_1324) but in works they deny _him,_ being abominable, and disobedient, and unto every good work reprobate.

verseText: But speak thou the things which become sound doctrine:
mdText: But speak thou the things which become sound doctrine:

verseText: That the aged men be sober, grave, temperate, sound in faith, in charity, in patience.
mdText: That the aged men be sober, grave, temperate, sound in faith, in charity, in patience.

verseText: The aged women likewise, that they be in behaviour as becometh holiness, not false accusers, not given to much wine, teachers of good things;
mdText: The aged women likewise, that _they_ _be_ in behaviour as becometh holiness, not false accusers, not given to much wine, teachers of good things;

verseText: That they may teach the young women to be sober, to love their husbands, to love their children,
mdText: That they may teach the young women to be sober, to love their husbands, to love their children,

verseText: To be discreet, chaste, keepers at home, good, obedient to their own husbands, that the word of God be not blasphemed.
mdText: _To_ _be_ discreet, chaste, keepers at home, good, obedient to their own husbands, that the word of [God]([/person/god_1324) be not blasphemed.

verseText: Young men likewise exhort to be sober minded.
mdText: Young men likewise exhort to be sober minded.

verseText: In all things shewing thyself a pattern of good works: in doctrine shewing uncorruptness, gravity, sincerity,
mdText: In all things shewing thyself a pattern of good works: in doctrine _shewing_ uncorruptness, gravity, sincerity,

verseText: Sound speech, that cannot be condemned; that he that is of the contrary part may be ashamed, having no evil thing to say of you.
mdText: Sound speech, that cannot be condemned; that he that is of the contrary part may be ashamed, having no evil thing to say of you.

verseText: Exhort servants to be obedient unto their own masters, and to please them well in all things; not answering again;
mdText: _Exhort_ servants to be obedient unto their own masters, _and_ to please _them_ well in all _things;_ not answering again;

verseText: Not purloining, but shewing all good fidelity; that they may adorn the doctrine of God our Saviour in all things.
mdText: Not purloining, but shewing all good fidelity; that they may adorn the doctrine of [God]([/person/god_1324) our [Saviour]([/person/jesus_905) in all things.

verseText: For the grace of God that bringeth salvation hath appeared to all men,
mdText: For the grace of [God]([/person/god_1324) that bringeth salvation hath appeared to all men,

verseText: Teaching us that, denying ungodliness and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world;
mdText: Teaching us that, denying ungodliness and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world;

verseText: Looking for that blessed hope, and the glorious appearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ;
mdText: Looking for that blessed hope, and the glorious appearing of the great [God]([/person/god_1324) and our [Saviour]([/person/jesus_905) [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ;]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: Who gave himself for us, that he might redeem us from all iniquity, and purify unto himself a peculiar people, zealous of good works.
mdText: Who gave himself for us, that he might redeem us from all iniquity, and purify unto himself a peculiar people, zealous of good works.

verseText: These things speak, and exhort, and rebuke with all authority. Let no man despise thee.
mdText: These things speak, and exhort, and rebuke with all authority. Let no man despise thee.

verseText: Put them in mind to be subject to principalities and powers, to obey magistrates, to be ready to every good work,
mdText: Put them in mind to be subject to principalities and powers, to obey magistrates, to be ready to every good work,

verseText: To speak evil of no man, to be no brawlers, but gentle, shewing all meekness unto all men.
mdText: To speak evil of no man, to be no brawlers, _but_ gentle, shewing all meekness unto all men.

verseText: For we ourselves also were sometimes foolish, disobedient, deceived, serving divers lusts and pleasures, living in malice and envy, hateful, and hating one another.
mdText: For we ourselves also were sometimes foolish, disobedient, deceived, serving divers lusts and pleasures, living in malice and envy, hateful, _and_ hating one another.

verseText: But after that the kindness and love of God our Saviour toward man appeared,
mdText: But after that the kindness and love of [God]([/person/god_1324) our [Saviour]([/person/jesus_905) toward man appeared,

verseText: Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost;
mdText: Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the [Holy]([/person/holy_spirit_7400) Ghost;

verseText: Which he shed on us abundantly through Jesus Christ our Saviour;
mdText: Which he shed on us abundantly through [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ]([/person/jesus_905) our [Saviour;]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: That being justified by his grace, we should be made heirs according to the hope of eternal life.
mdText: That being justified by his grace, we should be made heirs according to the hope of eternal life.

verseText: This is a faithful saying, and these things I will that thou affirm constantly, that they which have believed in God might be careful to maintain good works. These things are good and profitable unto men.
mdText: _This_ _is_ a faithful saying, and these things I will that thou affirm constantly, that they which have believed in [God]([/person/god_1324) might be careful to maintain good works. These things are good and profitable unto men.

verseText: But avoid foolish questions, and genealogies, and contentions, and strivings about the law; for they are unprofitable and vain.
mdText: But avoid foolish questions, and genealogies, and contentions, and strivings about the law; for they are unprofitable and vain.

verseText: A man that is an heretick after the first and second admonition reject;
mdText: A man that is an heretick after the first and second admonition reject;

verseText: Knowing that he that is such is subverted, and sinneth, being condemned of himself.
mdText: Knowing that he that is such is subverted, and sinneth, being condemned of himself.

verseText: When I shall send Artemas unto thee, or Tychicus, be diligent to come unto me to Nicopolis: for I have determined there to winter.
mdText: When I shall send [Artemas]([/person/artemas_315) unto thee, or [Tychicus,]([/person/tychicus_2885) be diligent to come unto me to [Nicopolis:](/place/nicopolis_894) for I have determined there to winter.

verseText: Bring Zenas the lawyer and Apollos on their journey diligently, that nothing be wanting unto them.
mdText: Bring [Zenas]([/person/zenas_3038) the lawyer and [Apollos]([/person/apollos_276) on their journey diligently, that nothing be wanting unto them.

verseText: And let ours also learn to maintain good works for necessary uses, that they be not unfruitful.
mdText: And let ours also learn to maintain good works for necessary uses, that they be not unfruitful.

verseText: All that are with me salute thee. Greet them that love us in the faith. Grace be with you all. Amen.
mdText: All that are with me salute thee. Greet them that love us in the faith. Grace _be_ with you all. Amen.

verseText: Paul, a prisoner of Jesus Christ, and Timothy our brother, unto Philemon our dearly beloved, and fellowlabourer,
mdText: [Paul,]([/person/paul_2479) a prisoner of [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ,]([/person/jesus_905) and [Timothy]([/person/timotheus_2863) _our_ brother, unto [Philemon]([/person/philemon_2342) our dearly beloved, and fellowlabourer,

verseText: And to our beloved Apphia, and Archippus our fellowsoldier, and to the church in thy house:
mdText: And to _our_ beloved [Apphia,]([/person/apphia_278) and [Archippus]([/person/archippus_292) our fellowsoldier, and to the church in thy house:

verseText: Grace to you, and peace, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
mdText: Grace to you, and peace, from [God]([/person/god_1324) our [Father]([/person/god_1324) and the [Lord]([/person/jesus_905) [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ.]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: I thank my God, making mention of thee always in my prayers,
mdText: I thank my [God,]([/person/god_1324) making mention of thee always in my prayers,

verseText: Hearing of thy love and faith, which thou hast toward the Lord Jesus, and toward all saints;
mdText: Hearing of thy love and faith, which thou hast toward the [Lord]([/person/jesus_905) [Jesus,]([/person/jesus_905) and toward all saints;

verseText: That the communication of thy faith may become effectual by the acknowledging of every good thing which is in you in Christ Jesus.
mdText: That the communication of thy faith may become effectual by the acknowledging of every good thing which is in you in [Christ]([/person/jesus_905) [Jesus.]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: For we have great joy and consolation in thy love, because the bowels of the saints are refreshed by thee, brother.
mdText: For we have great joy and consolation in thy love, because the bowels of the saints are refreshed by thee, brother.

verseText: Wherefore, though I might be much bold in Christ to enjoin thee that which is convenient,
mdText: Wherefore, though I might be much bold in [Christ]([/person/jesus_905) to enjoin thee that which is convenient,

verseText: Yet for love’s sake I rather beseech thee, being such an one as Paul the aged, and now also a prisoner of Jesus Christ.
mdText: Yet for love’s sake I rather beseech _thee,_ being such an one as [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) the aged, and now also a prisoner of [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ.]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: I beseech thee for my son Onesimus, whom I have begotten in my bonds:
mdText: I beseech thee for my son [Onesimus,]([/person/onesimus_2251) whom I have begotten in my bonds:

verseText: Which in time past was to thee unprofitable, but now profitable to thee and to me:
mdText: Which in time past was to thee unprofitable, but now profitable to thee and to me:

verseText: Whom I have sent again: thou therefore receive him, that is, mine own bowels:
mdText: Whom I have sent again: thou therefore receive him, that is, mine own bowels:

verseText: Whom I would have retained with me, that in thy stead he might have ministered unto me in the bonds of the gospel:
mdText: Whom I would have retained with me, that in thy stead he might have ministered unto me in the bonds of the gospel:

verseText: But without thy mind would I do nothing; that thy benefit should not be as it were of necessity, but willingly.
mdText: But without thy mind would I do nothing; that thy benefit should not be as it were of necessity, but willingly.

verseText: For perhaps he therefore departed for a season, that thou shouldest receive him for ever;
mdText: For perhaps he therefore departed for a season, that thou shouldest receive him for ever;

verseText: Not now as a servant, but above a servant, a brother beloved, specially to me, but how much more unto thee, both in the flesh, and in the Lord?
mdText: Not now as a servant, but above a servant, a brother beloved, specially to me, but how much more unto thee, both in the flesh, and in the [Lord?]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: If thou count me therefore a partner, receive him as myself.
mdText: If thou count me therefore a partner, receive him as myself.

verseText: If he hath wronged thee, or oweth thee ought, put that on mine account;
mdText: If he hath wronged thee, or oweth _thee_ ought, put that on mine account;

verseText: I Paul have written it with mine own hand, I will repay it: albeit I do not say to thee how thou owest unto me even thine own self besides.
mdText: I [Paul]([/person/paul_2479) have written _it_ with mine own hand, I will repay _it:_ albeit I do not say to thee how thou owest unto me even thine own self besides.

verseText: Yea, brother, let me have joy of thee in the Lord: refresh my bowels in the Lord.
mdText: Yea, brother, let me have joy of thee in the [Lord:]([/person/jesus_905) refresh my bowels in the [Lord.]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: Having confidence in thy obedience I wrote unto thee, knowing that thou wilt also do more than I say.
mdText: Having confidence in thy obedience I wrote unto thee, knowing that thou wilt also do more than I say.

verseText: But withal prepare me also a lodging: for I trust that through your prayers I shall be given unto you.
mdText: But withal prepare me also a lodging: for I trust that through your prayers I shall be given unto you.

verseText: There salute thee Epaphras, my fellowprisoner in Christ Jesus;
mdText: There salute thee [Epaphras,]([/person/epaphras_1195) my fellowprisoner in [Christ]([/person/jesus_905) [Jesus;]([/person/jesus_905)

verseText: Marcus, Aristarchus, Demas, Lucas, my fellowlabourers.
mdText: [Marcus,]([/person/mark_1679) [Aristarchus,]([/person/aristarchus_306) [Demas,]([/person/demas_1006) [Lucas,]([/person/luke_1836) my fellowlabourers.

verseText: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.
mdText: The grace of our [Lord]([/person/jesus_905) [Jesus]([/person/jesus_905) [Christ]([/person/jesus_905) _be_ with your spirit. Amen.
